# 1800\n
{London, British Library, Cotton Nero A xiv, fols. 120v-131v, hand B: Wooing Group texts}\n
C13a2\n
378 253 N\n
{=W Worcs=}\n
{=Sample represents all the text in English in this hand=}\n
{=Script - Textura semiquadrata=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{=Original transcript provided by JJS, corrected by ML=}\n
{164}\n
{London, British Library, Cotton Nero A.xiv, fols. 120v-123v: On god ureison of vre lefdi}\n
{~f120v~}\n
{=The text begins immediately below the end of the Ancrene Riwle in Hand\n
A, and slightly less than half way down the folio. The first letter of\n
each verse line is placed in a separately ruled column. Although these\n
are only occasional majuscule in shape, I take the separation to\n
distinguish them as litterae notabiliores and I have therefore\n
designated them as capitals with preceding asterisks=}\n
{\'}\n

the space of the title above it=}\n

$other?/aj-def_T+OdE $/TN-ad_T+\n
{=sic. MS TO dE linked with two horizontal strokes. There seems to be some\n
corruption in the text here. Morris (1868) and Thompson (1958) both assume\n
TO-dE is an error for "sooth". Given similar TU dE linked by horizontal\n
strokes below and standing for CUdE "make known" it would be plausible to\n
read COdE here. Cf. OED sv. cothe n. and MED s.v. coth n. from OE coYu\n
"pains, swooning". But the context here demands an adjective not a noun=}\n

\n
# 280\n
{London, British Library, Cotton Otho C xiii, fols 1r-146v: Layamon B}\n
C13b1\n
396 172 N\n
{=NW Wilts=}\n
{=Sample tagged: 1r-19rb=}\n
{=Script - Textura semiquadrata=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{=Note that the first folio containing the Preface and lines 1-37 are\n
missing as a result of the Cottonian fire. The missing text is\n
supplied in Brook and Leslie (B&L) and in Madden from Wanley\'s\n
transcript. I have not included it here but start from where the\n
MS text now begins. Even so, some of the readings are indecipherable\n
on microfilm and I have had to supply some readings from the editions\n
for the sake of readability, though these supplied readings are not\n
normally tagged. Madden\'s readings which are bracketed in B&L to\n
indicate that they are no longer visible are in square brackets. If\n
they form part of a word that is otherwise legible I occasionally\n
include the word in the tagged text. Otherwise it is excluded by a\n
leading !. Dots indicate illegible text - one dot per letter when\n
close together. When they are spaced, one dot represents an average of\n
two letters - as indicated in B&L. The text is not written in verse lines\n
but as if it is prose. The verse lines in B&L and Madden are editorial.\n
It is not always possible to make out from the microfilm where the MS\n
line endings are. Where I am not certain I give no notice of the line\n
end. I give MS punctuation either from the microfilm, or where it is\n
illegible on film, I follow B&L=}\n
{~f1ra~}\n
{=B&L p7=}\n

\n
# 147\n
{London, British Library, Cotton Roll ii.11, language A: 3 documents from Crediton}\n
C13b2\n
283 100 E\n
{=Crediton, Devon=}\n
{=Sample represents all the text in English in this hand=}\n
{=Script - Textura semi-quadrata. note that both insular g\n
(realised as g) and yogh (realised as z) are used=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
$/P11N+V_*H*ICH\n
{=Large initial *H=}\n
\'_EGGER\n
$bishop/n-t_BISCHOB\n

!_yAT\n
{=Davidson (1878) tranlates this as "concerning". So the whole clause would\n
read "I declare to all my successors in Crediton Minster, concerning the\n
forgiveness etc".  But the word "that" has no other recorded uses (as far\n
as I know) as a preposition meaning "about" so I prefer to take it as a\n
false start or as a dittography of the definite article following and\n
read "proclaim .... the forgiveness". This apparently follows MED\'s\n
reading which omits any mention of yAT preceding yE zEUENISSE=}\n
{\\}\n

{=MED cites MINE-DAgES from this text (s.v. mineday) as an example of the\n
OE mynedaeg "remembrance day". But the days in question here are days of\n
indulgence, and Bishop Living is here confirming the days of indulgence\n
gathered from various sources by Bishop Egger and adding to them those\n
gathered since and in his own day - MINE DAg+ES=}\n

$ruen/vps13_RUU+Ed $/vps13[N]_+Ed\n
{=Or read RUNEd "runs". Wilson (1938) reads RUNEd here but RUUEd in\n
Royal. He says (probably rightly) that RUNEd cannot be the correct reading\n
for semantic reasons and accepts Hall\'s (1928) suggestion that RUUEd is\n
from an otherwise unattested verb *ruuen related to "ruffle" meaning "to\n
stand on end". In fact the verb "ruff" is attested, albeit only from C16,\n
in the context of a hawk raising its feathers to a more erect position.\n
Here I follow MED\'s headword (from Bodley\'s RUEd) but acknowledging that\n
ruuen, rouen with intervocalic [v] is also possible=}\n

$fesken/vi-m_FESK+IN $/vi-m_+IN\n
{="swaddle?". Millett (1982) following Colborn (1940) suggests a\n
miswriting in the common exemplar of S for R and emends to FERKIN < OE\n
fercian. This usually means "convey, bring" but is attested in OE with\n
the meanings "support, feed". I think it unlikely, however, that the scribes\n
of both  B and T would have perpetuated such a mistake. I favour MED\'s\n
reading, which invokes Latin fasciare and OF faissier "swaddle". Godefroy\n
lists among the many attested forms for the related noun faisse, the variant\n
fesche. A form *fescher could be Anglicised as FESKIN in early Middle\n
English, cf. "task" < OF tasche=}\n
